generated_question:
A cinema sells tickets for adults and children. The prices are $12 for an adult and $7 for a child. On a particular Saturday, Cinema 1 sold 150 adult tickets and 80 child tickets, while Cinema 2 sold 200 adult tickets and 110 child tickets. This scenario is represented by the matrix \( V = \begin{bmatrix} 150 & 80 \\ 200 & 110 \end{bmatrix} \).

(i) Write a \( 2 \times 1 \) matrix, \( P \), to represent the price of the tickets.

(ii) Calculate the matrix \( T = VP \).

(iii) What does each element of matrix \( T \) represent?

citations.cited_text: The admission tickets to the Singapore Zoo are $50 for an adult, $36 for a child, and $20 for a senior citizen. On a particular Tuesday, there were 212 adults, 251 children, and 15 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo and on a particular Wednesday, there were 231 adults, 266 children, and 12 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo. The number of visitors on the particular Tuesday and Wednesday can be represented by the matrix V = \begin{pmatrix} 212 & 251 & 15 \\ 231 & 266 & 12 \end{pmatrix}. \text{ (i) Write a } 3 \times 1 \text{ matrix, P, to represent the price of the admission tickets. (ii) Find the matrix } T = VP. \text{ (iii) Explain what each of the elements represents. (iv) Find the total amount collected from the sales of the tickets for the 2 days.}

Two outlets of a coffee chain sell three different types of coffee: espresso, flat white and mocha. The table shows the number of cups of each type of coffee sold on a particular day. Outlet A: Espresso 30, Flat White 30, Mocha 35; Outlet B: Espresso x, Flat White x + 2, Mocha 40. This information can be represented by the matrix \( P = \begin{pmatrix} 30 & 30 & 35 \\ x & x+2 & 40 \end{pmatrix} \). The coffee chain sells a cup of espresso at $2.50, a cup of flat white at $4 and a cup of mocha at $5.50. This information can be represented by the matrix \( Q = \begin{pmatrix} 2.5 \\ 4 \\ 5.5 \end{pmatrix} \). (a) Find, in terms of x, the matrix \( R = PQ \).

generated_question:
The entry ticket prices for a botanical garden are $40 for an adult, $25 for a child, and $15 for a senior citizen. On a given Monday, 180 adults, 210 children, and 25 senior citizens visited the garden. On a particular Thursday, there were 200 adults, 195 children, and 30 senior citizens who visited the garden.

The number of visitors on these two days can be represented by the matrix \( V = \begin{bmatrix} 180 & 210 & 25 \\ 200 & 195 & 30 \end{bmatrix} \).

(i) Write a \(3 \times 1\) matrix, \( P \), to represent the price of the admission tickets.

(ii) Find the matrix \( T = VP \).

(iii) Explain what does each of the elements represents.

(iv) Find the total amount collected from the sales of the tickets for the two days.

\[ P = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 6 \\ 4.5 \end{bmatrix} \]

(ii) Explain what each element of the resulting matrix \( R \) represents.

generated_question: Sarah recorded the number of hours she spent reading each week for 9 weeks. The data she collected is shown in the following ordered list: \[ 3.5, 4, 5.5, 6, 6.5, 7, 8, 9, 10 \] Write down the median number of hours Sarah spent reading.

citations.cited_text:
Ethan measures the amount of rain, in millimetres (mm), each day for 31 days. The bar chart shows his results. 

(a) Write down the median amount of rain.

generated_question: P, Q, R, and S are four points on a circle with center X. PQ is a tangent to the circle at P and RQ is a tangent to the circle at R. Given that \( \angle PXQ = 148^\circ \) and \( \angle SPR = 38^\circ\), find the following: (a) Calculate (i) \( \angle PSR \), (ii) \( \angle QPR \). (b) Determine if XR is parallel to PS. Justify your reasoning.

citations.cited_text: A, D, B, and C lie on a circle, center O. AP is a tangent to the circle at A and BP is a tangent to the circle at B. \angle AOB = 142^\circ \text{ and } \angle DAP = 42^\circ. \text{ (a) Find the value of (i) } \angle ACB, \text{ (ii) } \angle ADB. \text{ (b) Is OB parallel to AD? Explain.}

generated_question: A speed-time graph depicts the journey of a cyclist accelerating from rest. It is a straight line passing through the origin, reaching a speed of 25 m/s at t = 10 seconds. (a) Calculate the acceleration of the cyclist at t = 6 seconds.

citations.cited_text: The diagram is the speed-time graph for the first k seconds of the motion of an object. (a) Find the acceleration when \( t = 5 \).
